United States Bureau of Drapery Containment (USBDC.gov) Issue 207 | Tuesday Edition | Verified at 06:11 ET by hand

Curtains Are Walls In Denial.

Acting Director Marjorie Pell reports from Desk 4B: if sunlight can negotiate through your "decor," so can uncertainty.

Federal Seal Notice:
Form V-12 (Visible Through Fabric) now accepted in blue ink, black ink, and one dramatic sigh.
Pell Promise: "I got trapped behind damask at age 9. I will not lose another child to decorative ambiguity."

Morning / Evening Desk

06:00 13,410 blinds calibrated to "truthful slat angle."

06:32 Nebraska resident self-reported a "sheer incident" before breakfast. Compliance excellent.

07:10 Marjorie Pell consumed one black coffee and rejected three euphemisms for "curtain."

18:04 91% of inspected drapes admitted they were "mostly emotional support."

19:12 Public hearing closed after witness brought tieback rope and called it "a legal fence."

20:00 Pell signs 42 permits with phrase: "Wall behavior requires wall paperwork."

Front Page Investigation

Operation Peekaboo Netted 312 Unlicensed "Soft Walls" in One Cul-de-sac

By Acting Director Marjorie Pell, founder, survivor, and the only federal employee who alphabetized drape folds for fun.

I started this bureau because at age nine I vanished behind my aunt's paisley curtain for four hours while adults debated whether I was "inside" or "adjacent." Policy was born from that silence. Yesterday, in Chandler, Arizona, we found residents calling curtains "privacy vibes" to dodge permit fees.

"A curtain is not innocent because it ripples. So does panic."

Inspectors issued restoration plans, including mandatory tieback drills and one community workshop titled "Windows: Pick A Side."

Section 14.2 compliant Gap measured to 1.5 mm Public briefing at noon

Desk Feed

Three Briefs You Can Quote At Dinner

Infrastructure:

Federal grant opens for curtain rod anchors rated for "argument-grade tension." Deadline March 14.

Science Desk:

Lab confirms 93% of dust returns within 48 hours when drape hems touch "the regret zone" of carpet.

Markets:

Velvet futures drop after Pell calls velvet "a confidence trick with tassels."

Civic Life:

County fair replaces pie contest with competitive window clarity. First prize: a vacuum and closure.

Corrections & Clarifications

Yesterday's issue stated drape rings are "always ornamental." In fact, ring #4 often bears load and emotional burden.

We misidentified Mr. Calvin Ortiz as a "shade extremist." He is a "blinds maximalist." The distinction matters in district court.

Photo caption now reads: "Pell nodding firmly," not "Pell smiling."

Letters To Director Pell

"My mother says curtains are about softness."
Dear agency, softness without boundaries is just confusion with tassels. Thank you for your service. - Bri, Akron

"Can I permit lace retroactively?"
Yes, if the lace admits what it is and pays the back fees. - Hector, Boise

"I hung a blanket over a door. Am I a criminal?"
Not yet. You are, however, on a journey. - Anonymous, probably Denver

Public Safety Meter

Green Curtain honesty up 11% nationwide.

Amber Rod overhang violations in suburban sunrooms.

Red One "boho veil wall" under federal review in Miami.

Tomorrow's Drill:

At 9:00 local time, pull your curtains halfway and ask, "What are we pretending right now?" Log answers in Form C-22.

Opinion

Op-Ed: "Stop Calling Them Window Dresses" by Juno Mehta. Garments are for bodies, not accountability evasion.

Counterpoint: "My Curtains Raised Me" by Todd H. (approved with edits and one wellness check).

Column: "Ask A Bureaucrat" - This week: can your shower curtain claim diplomatic immunity? Short answer: no.
